conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the given acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows acceleration (a) versus time (t). The acceleration changes linearly over time, forming a triangle wave. The key points on the time axis are 0, t0/2, t0, 3t0/2, and 2t0.
From 0 to t0/2, acceleration increases linearly to a0.
From t0/2 to t0, acceleration decreases linearly back to 0.
From t0 to 3t0/2, acceleration becomes negative, decreasing to -a0.
From 3t0/2 to 2t0, acceleration increases back to 0.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.

premise: Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
conclusion: We need to determine when the velocity is maximum, as this will indicate the farthest point from the start.

premise: Velocity will be maximum when the net area under the acceleration-time graph is greatest.
conclusion: The graph is symmetric in acceleration, and the velocity will peak when the net area under the curve is at its maximum.

premise: At t = t0, the acceleration returns to zero after reaching a0 and -a0.
conclusion: The velocity at t = t0 is the integral of the acceleration from 0 to t0, which is maximum before the acceleration becomes negative.

premise: The velocity at t = t0 is the integral of the acceleration from 0 to t0, which is maximum before the acceleration becomes negative.
conclusion: The particle is farthest from the starting point at t = t0, where the velocity is at its maximum before it starts to decrease due to negative acceleration.
